conclusion: The problem involves shadows cast by four different objects on a wooden floor.
There is a blue alarm clock labeled A, an egg labeled B, a black object that looks like a typewriter labeled C, and a carton of milk labeled D.
Each object is casting a shadow directly beneath them, indicated by red arrows pointing to the shadows.
The light source is initially assumed to be coming from directly above, casting shadows directly beneath each object.
The question asks what happens when the light source moves to the back left or right.
The alarm clock (A) is on the left, the typewriter (C) is below it, the egg (B) is to the right of the alarm clock, and the carton of milk (D) is further to the right and slightly in front.

premise: The general rule is that the shadow will be cast in the direction opposite to the light source.
conclusion: If the light source moves to the back left, objects on the left side will cast shadows towards the right.

premise: The further an object is from the new direction of the light source, the longer its shadow will be.
conclusion: If the light source moves to the back left, the shadows will become longer.
